title: Greek (1751) He Kaine Diatheke - Gospels
description:
The 1751 Greek New Testament, titled "He Kaine Diatheke. Novum Testamentum Graecum Editionis Receptae Cum Lectionibus Variantibus. NEC Non Commentario Pleniore Opera Joannis-Jacobi Wetstenii," is a significant publication in biblical scholarship. This work was compiled and edited by Johann Jakob Wettstein, a notable Swiss theologian and biblical scholar.

Wettstein's edition of the Greek New Testament is particularly distinguished for its incorporation of the Textus Receptus, or the "received text," which was the Greek text predominantly used in the Protestant church since its publication in the 16th century. This edition is also notable for including various textual variants, offering a broader view of the scriptural text and its transmission. Furthermore, Wettstein's comprehensive commentary provides in-depth scholarly insight into the New Testament.

Wettstein's work represents a significant step forward in the critical study of the New Testament text, particularly in its detailed attention to variant readings. His compilation and analysis have been influential in the field of biblical textual criticism, aiding scholars in understanding the complexities and history of the New Testament text.
